captions.text: Good morning John!

Last Sunday, tens of thousands of people took
to the streets in Hong Kong to protest. The

police reactions to these protests were, surprisingly,
intense - resulting in, get this, far more
people joining the protest!

This somewhat surprising result is only one
of the things that can be explained through

a better understanding of what Hong Kong is,
what those people are protesting about, and
what is motivating China.
A brief history! -

1847: Hong Kong, a sparsely populated island
off the southern coast of China, is ceded
to the United Kingdom after the Opium War.

1898: China and Hong Kong agree to a 99 year
lease of Hong Kong to the British Empire to
be a British Colony.

99 years! That's, that's plenty of time to
figure out - NOPE.

In the 90's, with the switch impending, the
appointed - NOT elected - Governor of Hong

Kong started to talk about how it would be
really great if Hong Kong were a democracy.

This is kinda hilarious after 150 years of
colonial rule.

China finds this, not just hilarious, but
also really annoying because China would like

to have Hong Kong's extraordinarily economically
important cake and also eat it.

1997: after 150 years of British rule, Hong
Kong becomes part of China. Kind of.

After 150 years, Hong Kong has its own dialect,
and judiciary, and taxes, and postal service,

and money, and culture! People from Hong Kong
are ethnically Chinese, and they feel connected

to the Chinese people, but they don't consider
themselves Chinese.

To get an idea of how weird this is, if you
wanted to go from China, to China, but you

happened to be crossing the Hong Kong border,
you have to get your passport stamped and
go through immigration.

To get a better idea of how weird this is,
during the 2008 Beijing Olympics, both China
and Hong Kong had separate teams... Same country!

At the root of it, this is all because what
Hong Kong is now is really great for China.

Not only would it be extremely difficult to
have Hong Kong run by the same system as China,

which would be COMPLETELY different from the
entire culture of Hong Kong, it would also

be bad for China! China wants Hong Kong to
be the thing that it is.

It's a capitalist powerhouse that was created
as a bridge between China and the capitalist
world.

Hong Kong houses the third largest stock exchange
in the world; the Hong Kong dollar is the
eighth most traded currency in the world!

For all that to keep working, Hong Kong kinda
has to be a thing that China finds really
uncomfortable - Free.
They call it, "one country, two systems."

Alright, this might be a little bit of a difficult
thing to understand. In America, we make fun

of a politician on TV. That's not just okay,
it's also, like, if that politician can handle

it, it's kind of a good thing for them - it
makes them seem more powerful.

In China, where everything is very tightly
controlled, that kind of criticism would make
a politician seem extremely weak.

So you have to imagine China as being run
by a culture that does not accept any kind
of derision or appearance of weakness.
They're crazy with the control.

China's national day was this week and they
let loose ten thousand doves in Tiananmen

Square - they cavity searched EVERY dove to
make sure there were no explosives inside
of them. That is what you think it is.

China's government attitude is a mixture of
immense pride in what they have done and vulnerability

- just fear of it falling apart. And that
might be somewhat warranted, because there

are lots of China that don't want to be areas
of China!

And with a weakening economy and the number
of protests in China growing, politicians

are worried about losing stability - and they
REALLY like stability.

Now add, to all of this, that the current
president of China, Xi Jingping, just did

a massive crackdown on corruption. This made
him a lot of enemies of the Chinese officials
who were benefiting from corruption.

You have a situation where the leadership
in Beijing really wants to appear strong and

in control and not at all weak, and is thus
not in any way interested to conceding to

the protests in Hong Kong, or even allowing
them to continue!

The protest, itself, does probably hurt Beijing
- though maybe not as much as they imagine

because people in Hong Kong and people in
China don't actually get along that well anymore

for reasons that, surprisingly, involve shopping
excursions.

Now I've gotten a long way into this and I
haven't even talked about the reason why people

started protesting last Sunday. And that's
kind of because, with all this background,

it starts to feel... inevitable. Like it's
just a thing that was gonna happen.

But here's the specifics - since the hand-off
of Hong Kong to China, it has been run, not

by a Governor or a mayor, but a Chief Executive
if it wasn't capitalist enough for you.

The Chief Executive is elected by a kind of,
like, weird electoral college composed mostly

of, like, business tycoons that represent
different constituencies, mostly corporate
constituencies.

Now, Hong Kong's constitution, which isn't
really a constitution, eventually calls for

the election of the chief executive by the
people, and not by a group of twelve hundred

people who have the exact same interests as
Beijing.

But, Beijing interprets that law a little
bit differently, saying that, yes, the citizens

of Hong Kong can elect their Chief Executive,
but they have to choose from a pool of candidates

that Beijing pre-selects for them. And that,
of course, is not a democracy.

Now maybe even more importantly, since the
1989 massacre at Tiananmen Square, the people

of Hong Kong have had a proud and strong history
of demonstration and protest. And the intense

response from the Hong Kong police was maybe
even more scary to the people of Hong Kong

than was the prospect of not being able to
elect their own leaders - because the people

of Hong Kong have never been able to elect
their own leaders but they HAVE been able
to freely protest.

Some people hope that, as Hong Kong was a
testing ground for China's unique form of

capitalism, it might also become a testing
ground for actual Chinese democracy. But the

cultural gap between the structure and control
of China and the freedom of Hong Kong may
be too big to bridge.

But while the protests are bad for the image
of Chinese leaders, quashing them would be

bad for the continued economic prosperity
of Hong Kong. And the protesters know that

they shouldn't mess too much with Beijing,
that's why they're directing most of their
ire at the Chief Executive.

China's state media, meanwhile, does report
on the protests in Hong Kong, just like they

reported on the protests of the Arab Spring.
But, as they did with the Arab Spring, they

focus on the chaos and inconvenience that
these protests bring.

And, really, what China needs is to stick
together and be stable. Yay, stability!

And with the protesters in Hong Kong protesting
in very calm and stable ways, there seems

to be a certain amount of agreement that stability
is good. There aren't very many voices calling

for Hong Kong to secede from China, though
China may be afraid that, with continued cultural
changes, that may eventually be the case.

But mostly, Hong Kong just wants to be Hong
Kong - and exceptional, unique place where

lots of amazing things happen. Just, ideally,
a Hong Kong with a little bit more control

over its own destiny for, really, the first
time in its entire existence.

But in the country where they check the butts'
of pigeons for explosives, having an entire

seven million person part of the country not
controlled by the central government, is maybe

not just scary, it might just be a completely
foreign concept.

But just as China found ways to allow actual
capitalism to occur within its borders, maybe

there's a way for actual democracy to occur
within its borders. That would be pretty amazing,

and that would be a pretty fantastic outcome
to this very, very weird story.
I guess we'll see.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.text:
Well, it's ironic HK wasn't any democratic state up until early nineties, 
and even then the democracy was sort of introduced to the people of HK as a 
necessity to somehow keep an important financial hub untouched by communism 
(or whatever China claims to be). People in fact responded very lazily and 
not without suspicion to the first Legco elections. The voting activity was 
rather low. However if John Major wouldn't take a stronger line for 
democracy in HK at around 1992 (i think?..) we could see another Hong Kong 
now, and well we love it as it is, so thanx to Britain for at least some 
kind of action before 1997. It's a fact that democracy of Hong Kong SAR is 
to some degree artificial, and it's civil society is very young to say the 
least (the history of rallies/protest is not what makes the society of HK 
"civil", but the current situation is of course possible because this 
history). But the new generation has basically shown that there is indeed 
civil society and it will stand for it's rights, essentially trying to say 
"don't touch our new way of life". This whole problem is a time bomb. Pity 
Hong Kong never had a chance to become like Singapore, historically there 
was some probability of this. At some point either China will displace this 
democracy of Hong Kong or it will itself become a democratic state with 
civil society. They don't take a violent action just because the city is 
extremely important to the world's economy, being a third important 
financial hub after New York and London. Same reason China agreed on many 
compromises before 1997. Summarizing, i think HKers should keep up the good 
work and non-violent protests for as long as it's needed until China will 
itself look more like a civil society, and hopefully gradually they will 
develop some kind of social democracy or whatever. Maybe by 2046, judging 
by their speed of evolving from communist to capitalist state both by 
economics and mentality.﻿

comments.author: Deviant Winter

comments.text:
A capitalist democracy is not perfect. No system is perfect. However, 
although there is inequality and big corporation interests and so on and so 
forth in the West, governments in the West do not censor dissents (although 
sometimes they do and there is limits to free speech, but in China no 
dissent is allowed). The problem in China is that the government think ONLY 
THEY ARE RIGHT, ONLY THEY HOLD THE TRUTH. So when you talk about democracy? 
To them, what democracy? There is no need for democracy. And of course the 
high ranking officials eschew democracy so they could keep exploiting 
people.

But what is really tragic is that the general public also think like this. 
The Chinese are much less tolerant of different opinions than westerners (I 
say this basing on my own experience). They above all do not think China is 
ready for democracy, for the so called reason that "without a strong 
one-party government, China is going to fall apart." But this argument is 
completely groundless. Also, the big problem is not that China has a 
one-party system (though the one-party system is a cause of many problems), 
but that the government (and sometimes the people as well) do not value 
different opinions and human lives.

I feel like I am going off tangent here, but the bottomline is problems in 
China are very complicated. And real change will not come until the public 
UNIFORMLY (intellectual unity is very important to any regime change) 
demand change and democracy, which will not happen anytime soon.﻿

comments.author: Ellen Wen

comments.text:
I agree most of the thing you talked about. But, Cantonese is not the same 
language as Mandarin, they are two different Chinese languages that share 
the same set of Chinese characters, and they are not dialect of each other. 
Cantonese is not unique in Hong Kong either. I am from a province in 
mainland China where Cantonese is widely spoken. And Canton ("Guangdong" in 
pinyin), is a province in mainland China.
Hong Kong people NEVER got to elect their leaders while under British 
control, and I think that Xi offering them to elect their own executive 
chief from the candidates Beijing selected is sort of a bridging and 
negotiation. It is certainly not real democracy but it is probably the best 
offer they can offer to Hong Kong under the current system. 
It is not like I am against democracy, of course I would like to vote for 
the candidate I want. I am just stating the facts, and certainly there is a 
long way to go for China democracy.
 Think about it, mainland Chinese people, like me, never get to elect their 
own leaders!﻿

comments.author: Johann Klein

comments.text:
Hank, it is a informative video for people outside China to make themselves 
think they once again know more about the world. But I think for me, this 
video only shows how little you understand about China. Some may say you 
have caught the point of the problem but trust me, you really have not. I 
can see your passion for freedom and democracy, and your support for the 
people in Hong Kong, to whom goes also my very own support. However in all 
these China-explaining videoes I've seen, there is one major problem, which 
also lies in this one: Ignoring the rest 1.2+ billion ordinary Chinese 
people and their thoughts and feelings as individuals. I can imagine whom 
you have talked to and what information you have got from them, but trust 
me again, they do not represent the majority. I am not saying I speak for 
the majority, but try to understand the country( and all the other 
countries) in plural ways. I know you are trying your best, but I'll say 
not for this video. It is true that it is hard to hear the opinions of the 
rest of the people who are whether silent or 'silenced', However if you 
don't get to know the thoughts of the vast population, you cannot really 
understand what is going on. So it is really kind of a mission impossible. 
Things are much more complicated in China than you think. It seems that 
people only cares about protesters in HK and politicians in Beijings, but 
what about all the other people in cities and towns you may never heard of? 
The point is that I wonder where you got the confidence from, or maybe this 
level of understanding is enough for most of the people outside China. So 
know more, think more before you explain some other places to people. It is 
an old video I know, I hope you are doing a much better job now. I really 
appreciate what you are doing. Good luck!﻿

comments.author: pohkhui

comments.text:
Very interesting video. Probably one of the most objective videos I have 
seen regarding the "recent" Hong Kong problem. At least, politically.
The culture aspect of the protest is quite understated by almost every 
report I have seen. I suppose "Mainlanders get out of here because we look 
down on you" is not a very internationally news worth title.
Not too be too dramatic, but the situation in Hong Kong is like what in 
German at the beginning of WWII (well at least kinda). When facing a 
slowing economy, large unemployment and weak, ineffective governing body, 
people generally tend to blame others who are different. In this case, Hong 
Kong choose the Mainland, because, well, "we are struggling and you are 
still throwing money away like nothing, and we have been looking down on 
you forever and now you seem to be doing better than us?! Unacceptable!!" 
Sound familiar? Blame every Mainlander (Jew) because their presence ruined 
Hong Kong (Germany).
At one side, the protesters do have their merits for pursuing democracy. 
The existing governing structure is not effective and does not seem to 
improve their living standard. On the other hand, Hong Kong wanting to 
eliminate all Mainland influence is a bit overkill. Traditional consumerism 
does show a strong demand is good for everyone (at least in the long run). 
With out strong demand from mainland china, how can Hong Kong maintain 
their growth and economy?
P.S. I do hope people don't take the Hong Kong, German analogy too 
seriously. I don't think there is a chance that the two situations would 
end up the same.﻿

comments.author: ak47ak476

comments.text:
As a teenage Hongkonger myself, I would just like to say that our culture 
are very different from the Mainland china people as well as people from 
Macau. We wrote completely different verisons of chinese and speak 
differently comparing to most parts of Mainland China. 

A lot of Hongkonger are prouder of being a Hongkonger than a Chinese 
(myself as well) Mainland Chinese's culture are a lot ruder than ours and 
dresses a lot different as well. However, their behaviors have improved 
over the years which I applaud.

You hv to understand one thing, we have different politics, educational, 
economical, legal system of Mainland China which bugs Mainland China 
because we can say whatever the hell we want in hk but if u dare to say 
smth bad abt China in Beijing, u could be arrested for treason and go to 
jail for yrs. We do stuff that they can't control. Such as protests, 
revolutions, posting stuff online, have discussions publicly about how we 
feel abt China and since we hv the freedom of speech in hk and not in 
china, there ain't a thing they can do. 

Therefore, they are trying to hv new ways to control us, such as not giving 
permission to protests on streets and the reason for the whole umbrella 
movement/ revolution--- the election system. In the basic law, it says a 
lot of crap abt how the chief of hk needs to be nominated by some certain 
type of ppl and would be accepted (idk the english) (任命)by the Mainland 
China. So long story short, they can say we don't like this guy and force 
us to choose somebody else. ﻿

comments.text:
I think Taiwan should also be included as "a part of China that doesn't 
want to be a part of China". Taiwan is like Hong Kong in the political 
prospective, Taiwan have also been offered the "one country, two systems" 
idea and were threatened if not accepting the offer. Taiwan is threatened 
to have war w/ China if Taiwan don't accept the "offer". As a Taiwanese, I 
can tell you that our military cannot possibly be compared to China's big 
ass army, we didn't have a choice. We are lucky though, to be able to have 
free elections and protest without having police/military violence against 
protesters.﻿

comments.text:
So funny watching these donkeys. HK people are the biggest hypocrites of 
the world. the most stubborn and insist that things should be done their 
way....the donkey way. e.g. when we play football....they don't allow free 
kicks....."because its a friendly"....WTF???? e.g. windows in winter time 
are kept open....WHO ON EARTH DOES THAT??!!!!! None of them have any 
general knowledge about anything other than their silly japanese wannabe 
anime collectibles and their obsession with the mobile phone and cosplay 
dress up bullshit....yet they think they can talk politics. Honestly 
....these childish protestors REALLY are disrupting a society which is

into the propaganda of "democracy". HKers stick to what you 
know.....android apps, anime and TVB shitty dramas with your shitty actors, 
while the rest of the world grows smarter than you monkeys. I have NEVER 
EVER had a rational and logical debate with a HKer who doesnt snap like an 
ape. usually it starts and ends with....."aaaiiiyaaa". Thats all HK ppl 
know to say...."aiiiyaaaaa". The stupidest place in the world is HONG KONG. 
Total fucking morons. You fuckers are so lucky CNN doesn't see you for the 
trash you really are. They claim they are different to chinese 
people....yet they pick their nose, burp out loud, snort like a pig, clip 
their nails in restaurants, are disrespectful to any other culture but 
their own, treat philipinos like slaves because they are too lousy to take 
care of their own shit by themselves, and then they have the shame to 
actually claim that they are so different to mainland Chinese. You fucking 
pigs are all the same. Don't try to act like you are western and know 
western ways. You have no fucking clue how to even BEHAVE like a human 
being. And if you hate me for saying this....fuck you. i've been living 
here for too long. I know chinese people (HK people...same trash) too well 
so don't try to bullshit me with "not all HKers are like that". If you live 
on the island.....you might as well be living in the UK. come and live in 
Kowloon/New territories.....more donkeyness going on here. 
Funny.....foreigners in HK island surround themselves with other foreigners 
and then think they know chinese people.﻿

comments.text:
+afy300 Read a few articles,
There was the one with a lot of Mainlandish dressing people hoarding 
supplies at Mannings. 
The one with local people taking newspaper again and again.
The one criticising Hong Kong people on taking the lift instead of taking 
the stairs as lazy.
The one criticise on opportunistic taxi driver and also on conspiracy 
theories of foreign influence typical of Chinese government propaganda.
The one sarcastic of Hong Kong's racist tendency and also sarcastic of Hong 
Kong people's abhorrence to Mainland people?
The post ascribing recent occupy movements to mainland people taking away 
supplies in suitcase trips etc.
The two letters signed Xi Jinping and CY Leung, I assume also sarcastic?
There's too much sarcasm to handle.
Seems pro-protestly inclined page(or not?)

Regarding the treatment of Filipino household workers,
they earn minimum wage and suffers the same disparity as local minimum wage 
earners, while receiving lodging in households they clean and cook for. 
They are maid like in every way. The only way I can defend is saying that 
local minimum wage earners are not in a much better environment.

I take the stairs and rarely take the lift.

I don't take free newspapers. Such actions are loathsome IMO. And I've 
never done this before.  

I've not met any Pakistani or any other minorities in HK. And I am unaware 
of unfair treatment. I do not consider myself to be racist in anyway.

Racism I've never encountered, but if minorities are in dire position, with 
HK people in full knowledge yet in utter apathy and indifference, HK people 
are detestable.

For I'm not fond of HK people and does not take pride in being one, I have 
no reason to be oblivious of our own fault. And I seek fair criticism for 
improvement. Your opinion is read. Thank you
comments.author: wai ho chan

comments.text:
+afy300 Ok, I admit defeat.
It may all well be a lie, democracy is fake, politicians are corrupt. Maybe

something?

And yes we exploit Filipino people like cigarette manufacturers does, and

abroad. And yes, I do know that word, exploit occurs to me when I typed the 
last comment.
Since HK people can't be good enough parents to stay at home to bond, maybe 
we should stop having kids.

You claim to have seen the world, and how backwards Hong Kong is, and how 
HK people are all stubborn and closed minded.
and I claim that you don't know Hong Kong at all. How you claim Hong Kong 
is functioning well, how you claim it was all just people who were deceived 
by a slogan.
I remember seeing people take meds for common cold on American TV drama. 
Maybe HKers are all taking too much meds.

I don't get how little things on football and opening windows and anime 
stuff all add up to a backwards place. But maybe I'm too obstinate (a 
little bit more rare but still common word to show you I don't suck) to 
understand.

Not all people know democracy fails and most get fooled by western 
propaganda. People better be all on politics before they are dumb enough go 
on to the street to disrupt such a well functioning city.

And I'm so rock like and not open minded I can't know how HK is different 
to the rest of the world.Because of that you can refuse to reply.

Believe what you want, I don't care. it's easy to teach open minded people 
but you are the least open minded person on HK in the entire universe! Best 
of luck.
comments.author: Calvin Wong

comments.text:
Ofcourse you contribute to modern day slavery! I don't approve of factory 
workers working like crazy in china for me to have an iPhone! I have never 
owned an iphone! Your people are exploiting filipinos. EXPLOITING (search 
it in the dictionary). If you dont understand this, you will understand it 
30 years later when you realise what you WERE doing was basically like what 
a cigarette manufacturer does. supply the shit and deny all responsibility. 
and YES....its not normal to take medicine for a simple cold. again....you 
dont seem to get it because you are in a bubble of your own.

And yes...those parents go to work and give the child a horrible upbringing 
and later family arguments occurr. why? because your child will treat you 
the way you treated them when they were small. And this is exactly what i 
mean....all you HKers think about is....which method makes more money? 
OKAY! this one is good! its all money money money with you guys. you will 
NEEEEEVERRRR understand why having helpers is soooooo fucked up and wrong. 
In the west....people like Bill Gates have maids. not average people.

Because HK people want to show off their little bit of wealth and are lazy, 
they hire a maid. You people have only recently SEEN a bit of money coming 
in....this is why you behave like this. you think im wrong? I dont care 
what you think cuz i have seen the world and your opinion is childish to 
me. I feel like im talking to a kid. You people are just too stubborn to 
accept your faults. If you cant take care of your kid by yourself.....dont 
have one. simple as that. If you are going to have one.....give the child 
everything including yourself and your time and attention (no this doesnt 
mean spoiling them and turning them into little bastards like your people 
often do). I HATE HK KIDS....they are the worst kids I have seen in the 
world. and its all the parents fault who are too stupid to know how to 
raise them properly.

Raise your kids like REAL mothers and fathers should, otherwise....like 
many of your families.....you kids will just leave you once they grow up 
because they did not feel enough bonding to even feel like they WANT to 
help you (this happens a lot in HK. there have been adverts on TV trying to 
encourage kids to stay in contact with their parents. but its the parents 
to blame). like i said.....you guys are totally backwards in everything you 
do. It may seem trivial to you about the football thing....but its proof of 
how backwards your thinking is. So yes, its little things here and there.

I'm not going to reply any more....because once again....you are one of the 
sheep who is too stubborn to realise the rest of the world functions in a 
different way. And yes mate....having political knowledge IS a prerequisite 
before you start disrupting the public with bullshit slogans like 
"democracy" (which is just an illusion for donkeys like your people to 
believe and sell themselves like whores to the west). If you dont know your 
info, dont comment because it makes you look stupid and you lose shame and 
respect. but oh.....HKers dont know what shame is. thats why they refuse to 
talk some heavy politics and can only shout out stupid immature slogans. 
you people are years behind my friend.

Western propaganda and its bullshit misguided a lot of people. and i find 
it so funny that you donkeys havent learnt from these mistakes and after 
OUR failure to implement democracy, due to OUR corrupt politicians and 
systems, NOW you guys have only just arrived and are being fooled so 
easily. believe what you want. I dont care. its easy to teach open minded 
people. but your people are the least open minded in the entire universe. 
its like trying to shape a piece of rock. thats how stubborn your people 
are. All the best.

comments.author: Andy Wong

comments.text:
We ask that the United Nations Human Rights Council launch a formal and 
unbiased enquiry on the Hong Kong SAR Police Force and Hong Kong SAR 
Government over the abovementioned actions that have violated the Universal 
Declaration of Human Rights, as well as to investigate the People’s 
Republic of China for the violation of Hongkongers’ right to take part in 
their government by denying their right to democratic elections for Hong 
Kong’s legislature and government. We also ask that the United Nations to 
ban the use of chemical weapons, including teargas, which are banned in 
war, against civilians and protesters.
